children.value: An airzooka can fire a pocket of air across a room by quickly firing a squirt of air out of an elasticated polythene bag.

If the volume of the air pocket is 
$\quantity{2}{litres}$
, what is the mass if the density of air is 
$\quantity{1.2}{kg\,  m\sup {-3}}$
 (there are 
$\quantity{1000}{litres}$
 in 
$\quantity{1}{m\sup {3}}$
)?

What is its kinetic energy if it crosses a 
$\quantity{6}{m}$
 wide room in 
$\quantity{0.4}{s}$
?
What is the momentum of the air pocket?

Before the air pocket is fired, it is stationary. It consists of air molecules moving around randomly at about 
$\quantity{500}{m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
 (a little faster than the speed of sound). If the average mass of one molecule is 
$\quantity{5\times 10^{-26}}{kg}$
, how many molecules are there in the 
$\quantity{2}{litres}$
 pocket of air?
What is the total kinetic energy of all of the molecules?
What is the total momentum of all of the molecules?

If the kinetic energy is calculated using the answer to part (1.) for the mass of the pocket, and the speed of the molecules is 
$\quantity{500}{m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
, do you obtain the same as the answer to part (5.), the total kinetic energy of the molecules?

Why can the answer to part (6.), the total momentum, not be calculated using the mass of the pocket in part (1.) and the 
$\quantity{500}{m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
 average speed of the molecules?
